repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - Sevastopol Heat Supply
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Completion Note for
            the Sevastopol Heat Supply Improvement Project in Ukraine,
            for which a Bank Loan of US$ 28.19 million was approved by
            the Board on March 22, 2001. The Bank Loan was to Ukraine
            (represented by the Ministry of Finance) to be lent to
            Sevastopol City State Administration (SCSA), the owner of
            the new heat supply company Sevteploservis. SCSA would, in
            turn, lend the proceeds of the Bank Loan to Sevteploservis.
            After a lengthy delay due largely to local politics, the
            Bank's Loan Agreement was signed on September 23,2002.
            However, the Loan did not become effective and, at the
            request of the Borrower (the Ministry of Finance) dated
            January 22,2003, the Loan was cancelled.

repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - Sevastopol Heat Supply
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Sevastopol Heat Supply Improvement
            Project, will increase the efficiency, enhance energy
            conservation, and improve reliability in the city's
            heating system, through the introduction of decentralized
            mini-boilers, and, will further promote cost recovery
            policies, and develop the new heating enterprise -
            Sevteploservis - which will operate on a commercial basis.
            The components call for: 1) supply and installation of
            decentralized, gas-fired boiler plants with auxiliaries.
            This will require design, and site management work, as well
            as mobile maintenance units, and tools to maintain the
            boiler plants. These plants will be connected to the
            existing gas network, whose relatively new gas network, has
            sufficient capacity, to reduce gas consumption in
            Sevastopol, as well as improve the gas network pressure in
            Crimea; 2) technical assistance for Sevteploservis financial
            management, which includes implementation support, social
            assistance support, and, a tariff study. The component
            includes training, and equipment, and software supply; and,
            3) incremental financial audits, regarding the initial five
            year implementation period of Sevteploservis.

repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - Sevastopol Heat Supply Project :
            environmental review

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the environmental assessment for
            the Sevastopol Heat Supply Project, which reviews the
            environmental legislation, verifying that the emission
            standards of the former Soviet Union, are still valid in
            Ukraine. Nonetheless, only standards for carbon monoxide,
            and nitrogen oxides emissions - from small boilers, burning
            different fuels - are available, and, no standards seem to
            be available for sulfur emissions, nor does any legislation
            cover larger boilers. Emissions from the current district
            heating estimates, are based on the energy situation in
            1993, and fuel consumption is based on information available
            from Sevteploenergo. Although, it is expected that fuel
            consumption will decrease, resulting in improved
            environmental conditions, mitigation include the change in
            fuel, from coal to gas, or oil, and the exchange of old
            boilers, which will improve the district heating system, and
            allow for consumers' energy savings. Emissions of
            carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur dioxides into the atmosphere
            will be reduced, limiting the emissions of greenhouse gases,
            causing less acidification, while improving also, the local
            atmosphere. Disposal of insulation materials are of great
            concern, thus new insulation materials will not contain CFC
            and HCFC. Though it is believed that asbestos exist, only
            during rehabilitation works will it possible to accurately
            minimize risks by containing asbestos material.
